Expectation1: Complete assigned tasks by the agreed deadlines
Situation1: The task feeds directly into the next teammate’s work and delays would ripple.
Expectation2: Greet clients and make them feel comfortable
Situation2: A nervous new client steps inside, glancing around the salon for direction.
Story: I was hunched over my laptop at the back of the salon, fingers flying across the keyboard as I tried to finish the report for my team. The deadline was in an hour, and I knew that if I didn’t send it on time, the next person wouldn’t be able to start their part. The pressure was mounting; I could almost feel my colleague’s anxious eyes on the clock from across the city. Just then, the bell above the door chimed. A young woman stepped in, clutching her bag, her eyes darting nervously around the salon. I could see her uncertainty, the way she hesitated at the threshold, clearly needing a warm welcome. My heart twisted. I knew how important it was to greet clients, to make them feel at ease from the moment they arrived. But my mind was still tangled in spreadsheets and deadlines, torn between the demands of my team and the needs of this anxious client. I hovered at my station, caught in the impossible pull of both worlds, unsure which expectation to meet first.
